body_html:
@lorenzo93 The GCC 6 STL headers exposed a bug in clang 3.6, which has been fixed upstream and will soon be merged into computecpp. Until then, it is possible to work around this by either using the GCC5 headers or libc++ (https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=24770)

@dvisockas the issue that you are seeing is fixed in benoitsteiner/tensorflow-opencl@3a0391a. This is effectively a namespace clash.
body_text:
@lorenzo93 The GCC 6 STL headers exposed a bug in clang 3.6, which has been fixed upstream and will soon be merged into computecpp. Until then, it is possible to work around this by either using the GCC5 headers or libc++ (https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=24770)
@dvisockas the issue that you are seeing is fixed in benoitsteiner/tensorflow-opencl@3a0391a. This is effectively a namespace clash.
body:
@lorenzo93 The GCC 6 STL headers exposed a bug in clang 3.6, which has been fixed upstream and will soon be merged into computecpp. Until then, it is possible to work around this by either using the GCC5 headers or libc++ (https://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=24770) 

@dvisockas the issue that you are seeing is fixed in https://github.com/benoitsteiner/tensorflow-opencl/pull/31/commits/3a0391a796ed77f7fbd3fdd3c073bbe271f9bedd. This is effectively a namespace clash.
